editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

note.p: S.R. = Samuel Rowley; but often attributed to Thomas Dekker, and possibly revised by him from a work by Rowley. Probably with additions by John Day.
Running title reads: The noble Spanish souldier.

div.p: The noble soldier. Or, a contract broken, justly revenged.
div.l: Quam nescis artifices, arte perire sua.
div.p: London: printed for Nicholas Vavasour, and are to be sold at his shop in the temple, near the church. 1634.

div.head: The Printer to the reader.
div.p:
Understanding reader, I present this to your view, which has received applause in action. The poet might conceive a complete satisfaction upon the stages approbation: but the printer rests not there, knowing that that which was acted and approved upon the stage, might be no less acceptable in print. It is now communicated to you whose leisure and knowledge admits of reading and reason: your judgement now this Posthumus assures himself will well attest his predecessors endeavours to give content to men of the ablest quality, such as intelligent readers are here conceived to be. I could have troubled you with a longer epistle, but I fear to stay
you from the book, which affords better words and matter than I can. So the work modestly depending in the scale of your judgement, the printer for his part craves your pardon, hoping by his promptness to do you greater service, as conveniency shall enable him to give you more or better testimony of his entireness towards you.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item: Onelia, niece to Medina, the contracted lady.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter in magnificent state, to the so●nd of loud music, the King and Queen, as from church, attended by the Cardinal, count Malateste, Daenia, Roderigo, Valasco, Alba, Carlo, and some waiting ladies. The King and Queen with courtly compliments salute and part; she with one half attending her: King, Cardinal, and th'other half stay, the King seeming angry and desirous to be rid of them too. — King Cardinal, Daenia, etc.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Give us what no man here is master of,
(Breath) leave us pray, my father Cardinal
Can by the physic of philosophy
Et all again in order. Leave us, pray. exeunt

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How is it with you, sir?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: As with a ship
Now beat with storms, now safe, the storms are vanished,
And having you my pilot, I not only
See shore, but harbour; ay, to you will open
the book of a black sin, deep-printed in me:
O father! my disease lies in my soul.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The old wound, sir?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yes that, it festers inward:
For though I have a beauty to my bed
That even creation envies at, as wanting
Stuff to make such another, yet on her pillow
I lie by her, but an adulterer,
And she as an adulteress, she's my Queen
And wife, yet but my strumpet, though the church
Set on the seal of marriage; good Onaelia,
Niece to our lord high constable of Spain,
Was precontracted mine.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Yet when I stung
Your conscience with remembrance of the act,
Your ears were deaf to counsel.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I confess it.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Now to untie the knot with your new Queen
Would shake your crown half from your head.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Even Troy
(Though she hath wept her eyes out) would find tears
To wail my kingdom's ruins.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What will you do then?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: She has that contract written, sealed by you,
And other churchmen (Witnesses unto't)
A kingdom should be given for that paper.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I would not, for what lies beneath the moon,
Be made a wicked engine to break in pieces
That holy contract.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis my soul's aim to tie it
Upon a faster knot.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I do not see
How you can with safe conscience get it from her.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Oh! I know
I wrestle with a lioness: to imprison her,
And force her to't, I dare not: death! what King
Did ever say I dare not? I must have it:
a bastard have I by her, and that cock
Will have (I fear) sharp spurs, if he crow after
Him that trod for him: something must be done
Both to the hen and chicken; haste you therefore
To sad Onaelia, tell her I'm resolved
To give my new hawk bells, and let her fly:
My Queen I'm weary of, and her will marry:
To this our text add you what gloss you please,
The secret drifts of Kings are depthless seas.

div.stage: A table set out covered with black: two waxen tapers: the King's picture at one end, a crucifix at the other, Onaelia walking discontentedly weeping to the crucifix, her maid with her, to them cornego.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: O sorrow, sorrow, say where dost thou dwell?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: In the lowest room of hell.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: Art thou born of humane race?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: No, no, I have a furier face.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: Art thou in city, town or court?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: I to every place resort.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: O why into the world is sorrow sent?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: Men afflicted, best repent.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: What dost thou feed on?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: Broken sleep.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: What takest thou pleasure in?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: To weep,
To sigh, to sob, to pine, to groan,
To wring my hands, to sit alone.

sp.speaker: Question
sp.l: O when? o when shall sorrow quiet have?

sp.speaker: Answer
sp.l: Never, never, never, never,
Never till she finds a grave.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: No lesson, madam, but Lacrymae's? if you had buried nine husbands, so much water as you might squeeze out of an onion had been tears enough to cast away upon fellows that cannot thank you, come be jovial.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Sorrow becomes me best.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: A suit of laugh and lie down would wear better.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: What should I do to be merry, Cornego?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Be not sad.

sp.speaker: Ona.
sp.l: But what's the best mirth in the world?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Marry this, to see much, say little, do little, get little, spend little, and want nothing.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: O but there is a mirth beyond all these:
This picture has so vexed me, I'm half mad,
To spite it therefore I'll sing any song
Thyself shalt tune; say then what mirth is best?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Why then, madam, what I knock out now is the very marrowbone of mirth, and this it is.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: The best mirth for a lawyer is to have fools to his clients: for citizens, to have noblemen pay their debts: for tailors to have store of satin brought in, for then how little soe'er their houses are, they'll be sure to have large yards: the best mirth for bawds is to have fresh handsome whores, and for whores to have rich gulls come aboard their pinnaces, for then they are sure to build gally-asles.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.p: These to such souls are mirth, but to mine none: away.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Peace to you, lady.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I will not sin so much as hope for peace,
And 'tis a mock ill suits your gravity.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I come to knit the nerves of your lost strength,
To build your ruins up, to set you free
From this your voluntary banishment,
And give new being to your murdered same.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: What Aeseulapius can do this?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The King — 'tis from the King I come?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: A name I hate;
O I am deaf now to your embassy.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Hear what I speak.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Your language breathed from him
Is death's sad doom upon a wretch condemned.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Is it such poison?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Yes, and were you crystal,
What the King fills you with, would make you break:
You should (My lord) be like these robes you we are,
(Pure as the dye) and like that reverend shape;
Nurse thoughts as full of honour, zeal, and purity;
You should be the court-diall, and direct
The King with constant motion, be ever beating
(Like to clocke-hammers) on his iron heart
To make it sound clear, and to feel remorse
You should unlock his soul, wake his dead conscience,
Which like a drowsy sentinel gives leave
For sins vast army to beleaguer him;
His ruins will be asked for at your hands.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I have raised up a scaffolding to save
Both him and you from falling, do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Be dumb for ever.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Let your fears thus die:
By all the sacred relics of the church,
And by my holy order, what I minister
Is even the spirit of health.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I'll drink it down into my soul at once.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: But swear.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What conjurations can more bind mine oath?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: But did you swear in earnest?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Come, you trifle.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: No marvel, for my hopes have been so drowned,
I still despair: say on.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The King repents.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Pray that again, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The King repents.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: His wrongs to me?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: His wrongs to you: the sense
Of sin has pierced his soul.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Blessed penitence!

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: 'Has turned his joys into his leprous bosom,
And like a King vows execution
On all his traitorous passions.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Godlike justice!

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Intends in person presently to beg
Forgiveness for his acts of heaven and you.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Heaven pardon him, I shall.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Will marry you.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Umh! marry me? will he turn bigamist?
When, when?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Before the morrow sun hath rode
Half his day's journey; will send home his Queen
As one that stains his bed, and can produce
Nothing but bastard issue to his crown:
Why how now? lost in wonder and amazement?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I am so stored with joy that I can now
Strongly wear out more years of misery
Than I have lived.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You need not: here's the King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: With pardon, sir, I will prevent you,
And charge upon you first.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis granted, do:
But stay, what mean these emblems of distress?
My picture so defaced! opposed against
A holy cross! room hung in black! and you
Dressed like chief mourner at a funeral?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Look back upon your guilt (Dear sir) and then
The cause that now seems strange, explains itself:
This, and the image of my living wrongs
Is still confronted by me to beget
Grief like my shame, whose length may outlive time:
This cross, the object of my wounded soul,
To which I pray to keep me from despair;
That ever as the sight of one throws up
Mountains of sorrows on my accursed head:
turning to that, mercy may check despair,
And bind my hands from wilful violence.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But who hath played the tyrant with me thus?
And with such dangerous spite abused my picture?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: The guilt of that lays claim, sir, to yourself,
For being by you ransacked of all my fame,
Robbed of mine honour, and dear chastity,
Made by you act the shame of all my house,
The hate of good men, and the scorn of bad,
The song of broom-men, and the murdering vulgar,
And left alone to bear up all these ills
By you begun, my breast was filled with fire,
And wrapped in just disdain, and like a woman
On that dumb picture wreaked I my passions.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And wished it had been I.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Pardon me, sir,
My wrongs were great, and my revenge swelled high.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I will descend, and cease to be a King,
To leave my judging part, freely confessing
Thou canst not give thy wrongs too ill a name.
And here to make thy apprehension full,
And seat thy reason in a sound belief,
I vow tomorrow (Ere the rising sun
Begin his journey) with all ceremonies
Due to the church, to seal our nuptials,
To prive thy son with full consent of state,
Spain's heir apparent, born in wedlock vows.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: And will you swear to this?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: By this I swear.

sp.speaker: Ona.
sp.l: O you have sworn false oaths upon that book.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why then by this.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Take heed you print it deeply:
How for your concubine (Bride I cannot say)
She stains your bed with black adultery:
And though her fame masks in a fairer shape
Than mine to the world's eye, yet (King) you know
Mine honour is less strumpeted than hers,
however butchered in opinion.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This way for her, the contract which thou hast
By best advice of all our Cardinals,
Today shall be enlarged, till it be made
Passed all dissolving: then to our counsel-table
Shall she be called, that read aloud, she told
The church commands her quick return for Florence,
With such a dower as Spain received with her,
And that they will not hazard heavens dire curse
To yield to a match unlawful, which shall taint,
The issue of the King with bastardy:
This done, in state majestic come you forth
(Our new crowned Queen) in sight of all our peers:
Are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: To doubt of this were treason,
Because the King has sworn it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And will keep it:
Deliver up the contract then, that I
May make this day end with thy misery.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Here, as the dearest jewel of my fame,
Locked i this parchment from all viewing eyes,
This your indenture held alone the life
Of my supposed dead honour; yet (Behold)
Into your hands I redeliver it.
O keep it, sir, as you should keep that vow,
To which (Being signed by heaven) even angels bow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis in the lions paw, and who dares snatch it?
Now to your beads and crucifix again.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Defend me heaven!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Pray there may come ambassadors from France,
Their followers are good customers.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Save me from madness!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Twill raise the price, being the King's mistress.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: You do but counterfeit to mock my joys.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Away bold strumpet.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Are there eyes in heaven to see this?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Call and try, here's a whore's curse,
to fall in that belief which her sin's nurse.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How now? what quarter of the moon has she cut out now? my lord puts me into a wise office, to be a mad woman's keeper: why madam!

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Ha! where is the King, thou slave?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Let go your hold, or I'll fall upon you as I am a man.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Thou treacherous caitiff, where's the King?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He's gone, but not so far gone as you are.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Crack all in sunder, o you battlements,
And grind me into powder.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What powder? come, what powder? when did you ever see a woman grinded into powder? I am sure some of your sex powder men and pepper 'em too.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Is there a vengeance
Yet lacking to my ruin? let it fall,
Now let it fall upon me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No, there has too much fallen upon you already.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Thou villain, leave thy hold, I'll follow him:
Like a raised ghost I'll haunt him, break his sleep,
Fright him as he's embracing his new leman,
Till want of rest bids him run mad and die,
For making oaths bawds to his perjury.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray be more seasoned, if he made any bawds he did ill, for there is enough of that fly-blown flesh already.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I'm now left naked quite:
All's gone, all, all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No madam, not all, for you cannot be rid of me:
Here comes your uncle.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Attired in robes of vengeance, are you, uncle?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: More horrors yet?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: 'Twas never full till now;
And in this torrent all my hopes lie drowned.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Instruct me in the cause.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: The King, the contract!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: There's cud enough for you to chew upon.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What's this? A riddle! how? the King, the contract!
The mischief I divine, which proving true,
Shall kindle fires in Spain to melt his crown
Even from his head: here's the decree of fate,
A black deed must a black deed expiate.

div.head: Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Thou god of good apparel, what strange fellows
Are bound to do thee honour! Mercer's books
Show men's devotions to thee; heaven cannot hold
A saint so stately: do not my dons know me
Because I'm poor in clothes? stood my beaten tailor
Plaiting my rich hose, my silk stocking-man
Drawing upon my lordship's courtly calf
Pairs of embroidered things, whose golden clocks
Strike deeper to the faithful shopkeepers heart
Than into mine to pay him. — had my Barbour
Perfumed my lousy thatch here, and poked out
Me tusks more stiff than are a cat's muschatoes,
These pied-winged butterflies had known me then●
Another flyboat save thee, illustrious don.
Sir is the King at leisure to speak Spanish
With a poor soldier?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: No, sirrah, you, no!
You done with th'ochre face, I wish to ha' thee
But on a breach, stifling with smoke and fire,
And for thy no, but whiffing gunpowder
Out of an iron pipe, I wooed but ask thee
If thou wouldst on, and if thou didst cry no,
Thou shouldst read canon-law, I'd make thee roar,
and wear cut-beaten-satin; I wooed pay thee
Though thou payest not thy mercer: mere Spanish jennets,
Signior is the King at leisure?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: To do what?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: To hear a soldier speak.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am no earpicker
To sound his hearing that way.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Are you of court, sir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: Yes, the King's barber.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: That's his earpicker: your name, I pray.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: Don Cockadilio:
If, soldier, thou hast suits to beg at court,
I shall descend so low as to betray
Thy paper to the hand royal.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I beg, you whoreson Muscod! my petition
Is written on my bosom in red wounds.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am no barbar-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: You yellow hammer, why shaver:
That such poor things as these, only made up
Of tailor's shreds and merchants silken rags,
And apothecary drugs to lend their breath
Sophisticated smells, when their rank guts
Stink worse than cowards in the heat of battle;
Such whalebond-doublet-rascals, that owe more
To laundresses and sempsters for laced linen
Then all their race from their great grandfather
To this their reign, in clothes were ever worth:
These excrements of silkworms! o that such flies
Do buzz about the beams of majesty!
Like earwigs, tickling a King's yielding ear
With that court-organ (Flattery) when a soldier
Must not come near the court gates twenty score,
But stand for want of clothes, (Though he win towns)
Amongst the almesbasket-men! his best reward
Being scorned to be a fellow to the black guard:
Why should a soldier (Being the world's right arm)
Be cut thus by the left? (A courtier?)
sp.p: Is the world all ruff and feather, and nothing else? shall I never see a tailor give his coat with a difference from a gentleman?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Baltazar!
Let us make haste to meet thee: how art thou altered?
Do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Alanz.
sp.l: Yes, sir, the brave soldier
Employed against the Moors.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Half turned Moor!
I'll honour thee, reach him a chair, that table,
And now aeneas-like let thine own trumpet
Sound forth thy battle with those slavish Moors.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: My music is a cannon; a pitchy field my stage; furies the actors, blood and vengeance the scene; death the story; a sword imbrued with blood, the pen that writes, and the poet a terrible buskined tragical fellow, with a wreath about his head of burning match instead of bays.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: On to the battle.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: 'Tis here without bloodshed: this our main battalions, that the van, this the vaw, these the wings, here we fight, there they fly, here they ensconce, and here our sconces lay 17 moons on the cold earth.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This satisfies mine eye, but now mine ear
Must have his music too; describe the battle.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The battle? Am I come from doing to talking? The hardest part for a soldier to play is to prate well; our tongues are fifes, drums, petronels, muskets, culverin and cannon, these are our roarers; the clocks whieh we go by, are our hands; thus we reckon ten, our swords strike eleven, and when steel targets of proof clatter one against another, then 'tis noon, that's the height and the heat of the day of battle.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
To that heat we came, our drums beat, pikes were shaken and shivered, swords and targets clashed and clattered, muskets rattled, canons roared, men died groaning.
brave laced jerkins and feathers looked pale, tottered rascals fought pell-mell ; here fell a wing, there heads were lost like footballs; legs and arms quarrelled in the air, and yet lay quietly on the earth; horses trampled upon heaps of carkafles, troops of carbines tumbled wounded from their horses; we besiege Moors, and famine us, mutinies bluster and are calm; I vowed not to doff mine armour, though my flesh were frozen to't and turned into iron, nor to cut head nor beard till they yielded; my hairs and oath are of one length, for (With Caesar) thus write I mine own story, veni, vidi, vici.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A pitched field quickly fought: our hand is thine;
And 'cause thou shalt not murmur that thy blood
Was lavished forth for an ingrateful man,
Demand what we can give thee, and 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Only your love.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis thine, rise, soldier's best accord
When wounds of wrongs are healed up by the sword.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Let me come in, I'll kill that treacherous King
The murderer of mine honour, let me come in.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What woman's voice is that?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Medina's niece.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bar out that fiend.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I'll tear him with my nails,
Let me come in, let me come in, help, help me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Keep her from following me; a guard.

sp.speaker: Alanz.
sp.l: They are ready, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let a quick summons call our lords together;
This disease kills me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Sir I would be private with you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Forbear us, but see the doors well guarded.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Will you, sir, promise to give me freedom of speech?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Yes I will, take it, speak any thing, 'tis pardoned.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: You are a whore master; do you send me to win towns for you abroad, and you lose a kingdom at home?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: What kingdom?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The fairest in the world, the kingdom of your fame, your honour.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I'll be plain with you; much mischief is done by the mouth of a cannon, but the fire begins at a little touchhole; you heard what nightingale sung to you even now.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Angels erred but once and fell, but you, sir, spit in heaven's face every minute, and laugh at it: laugh still; follow your courses; do; let your vices run like your kennels of hounds yelping after you, till they pluck down the fairest head in the herd, everlasting bliss.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Any more?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Take sin as the English snuffed tobacco, and scornfully blew the smoke in the eyes of heaven, the vapour flies up in clouds of bravery; but when 'tis out, the coal is black (Your conscience,) and the pipe stinks; a sea of rose-water cannot sweeten your corrupted bosom.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Nay, spit thy venom.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: 'Tis aqua coelestis, no venom; for when you shall clasp up those two books, never to be opened again, when by letting fall that anchor, which can never more be weighed up, your mortal navigation ends: then there's no playing at spurn-point with thunderbolts. A vintner then for unconscionable reckoning, or a tailor for unmeasurable items shall not answer in half that fear you must.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: No more.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I will follow truth at the heels, though her foot beat my gums in pieces.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: The barber that draws out a lion's tooth curseth his trade; and so shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Because you have beaten a few base-born Moors,
Methink'st thou to chastise? what's past I pardon,
Because I made the key to unlock thy railing;
But if thou dar'st once more be so untuned,
I'll send thee to the galleys, who are without there:
How now?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: In danger, sir?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yes, yes, I am; but 'tis no point of weapon
Can rescue me; go presently and summon
All our chief grandoes, Cardinals, and lords
Of Spain to meet in counsel instantly:
We called you forth to execute a business
Of another strain, — but 'tis no matter now
Thou diest, when next thou furrowest up our brow●

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: So: die!

div.stage: Enter Cardinal, Roderigo, Albia, Daenia, Valasco.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I find my sceptre shaken by enchantments
Charactered in this parchment, which to unloose,
I'll practise only countercharms of fire,
And blow the spells of lightning into smoke:
Fetch burning tapers.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Give me audience, sir;
My apprehension opens me a way
To a close fatal mischief, worse than this
You strive to murder; oh this act of yours
Alone shall give your danger's life, which else
Can never grow to height; do, sir, but read
A book here clasped up, which too late you opened,
Now blotted by you with foul marginal notes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Art frantic?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You are so, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: If I be,
Then here's my first mad fit.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: For honour's sake,
For love you bear to conscience. —

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Reach the flames:
Grandoes and lords of Spain be witness all
What here I cancel; read, do you know this bond?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Our hands are to't.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: 'Tis your confirmed contract
with my sad kinswoman: but wherefore, sir,
Now is your rage on fire, in such a presence
To have it mourn in ashes?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Marquess Daenia,
We'll lend that tongue, when this no more can speak.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Dear sir!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am deaf,
Played the full consort of the spheres unto me
Upon their loudest strings — so burn that witch
Who would dry up the tree of all Spain's glories,
But that I purge her sorceries by fire:
Troy lies in cinders; let your oracles
Now laugh at me if I have been deceived
By their ridiculous riddles: why (Good father)
(Now you may freely chide) why was your zeal
Ready to burst in showers to quench our fury?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Fury indeed, you give it proper name:
What have you done? closed up a festering wound
Which rots the heart: like a bad surgeon,
Labouring to pluck out from your eye a moat,
You thrust the eye clean out.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou'rt mad ex tempore:
What eye? which is that wound?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: That scroll, which now
You make the black indenture of your lust,
Although eat up in flames, is printed here,
In me, in him, in these, in all that saw it,
In all that ever did but hear 'twas yours:
That scold of the whole world (Fame) will anon
Rail with her thousand tongues at this poor shift
Which gives your sin a flame greater than that
You lent the paper; you to quench a wild fire,
Cast oil upon it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Oil to blood shall turn,
I'll lose a limb before the heart shall mourn.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: He's mad with rage or joy.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: With both; with rage
To see his follies checked, with fruitless joy
Because he hopes his contract is cut off
Which divine justice more exemplifies.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Where's the King?

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: Wrapped up in clouds of lightning?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What has he done? saw you the contract torn
As I did hear a minion swear he threatened.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He tore it not, but burned it.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Openly!

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: And heaven with us to witness.

sp.speaker: Maed.
sp.l: Well, that fire
Will prove a catching flame to burn his kingdom.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Meet and consult.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No more, trust not the air
With our projections, let us all revenge
Wrongs done to our most hoble kinswoman;
Action is honour's language, swords are tongues,
Which both speak best, and best do right our wrongs.

div.stage: Enter Onaelia one way, Cornego another.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam, there's a bear without to speak with you.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: A bear.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It's a man all hairy, and that's as bad.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis one master captain Baltazar.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: I do not know that Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He desires to see you: and if you love a water-spaniel
Before he be shorn, see him.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hist; a duck, a duck; there she is, sir.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: A soldiers good wish bless you lady.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Good wishes are most welcome (Sir) to me ▪
So many bad ones blast me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I scarce know myself.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I ha' been at tennis, madam, with the King: I gave him 15 and all his faults, which is much, and now I come to toss a ball with you.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.p: I am bandied too much up and down already.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, she has been struck under line, master Sould●.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I conceit you, dare you trust yourself alone with me?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I have been laden with such weights of wrong,
That heavier cannot press me: hence Cornego.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hence Cornego? stay captain: when man and woman are put together, some egg of villainy is sure to be sat upon.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: What would you say to him should kill this man that hath you so dishonoured?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: O I wooed crown him
With thanks, praise, gold, and tender of my life.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Shall I be that German fencer, and beat all the knocking boys before me? shall I kill him?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.p: There's music in the tongue that dares but speak it.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: That fiddle then is in me, this arm can do't, by poniard, poison, or pistol: but shall I do't indeed?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: One step to humane bliss is sweet revenge.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Stay; what made you love him?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: His most goodly shape,
Married to royal virtues of his mind.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Yet now you would divorce all that goodness; and why? For a little lechery of revenge? it's a lie: the burr that sticks in your throat is a throne; let him out of his mess of kingdoms; cut out but one, and lay Sicilia, Arragon, Naples, or any else upon your trencher, and you'll praise bastard for the sweetest wine in the world, and call for another quart of it: 'tis not because the man has left you, but because you are not the woman you would be, that mads you: a shee-cuckold is an untameable monster.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Monster of men thou art; thou bloody villain,
Traitor to him who never injured thee;
Dost thou profess arms? and art bound in honour
to stand up like a brazen wall to guard
Thy King and country, and wouldst thou ruin both?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: You spur me on to't.

sp.speaker: On●●.
sp.l: True;
Worse am I then the horrid'st fiend in hell
To murder him whom once I loved too well:
For though I could run mad, and tear my hair,
And kill that godless man that turned me vile,
Though I am cheated by a perjurous prince
Who has done wickedness, at which even heaven
Shakes when the sun beholds it, oh yet I'd rather
Ten thousand poisoned poniards stabbed my breast
Than one should touch his: bloody slave! I'll play
Myself the hangman, and will butcher thee
If thou but prick'st his finger.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Saist thou ●ne so! give me thy goll, thou art a noble girl; I did play the devil's part, and roar in a feigned voice, but I am the honestest devil that ever spit fire: I would not drink that infernal draught of a King's blood, to go recling to damnation, for the weight of the world in diamonds.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Art thou not counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Now by my scars I am not.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I'll call thee honest soldier then, and woo thee
To be an often visitant.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Your servant;
Yet must I be aston● upon a hill,
For though I do no good, I'll not lie still.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: When first you came from Florence, would the world
Had with an universal dire eclipse
been over whelmed, no more to gaze on day,
That you to Spain had never found the way,
Here to be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We from one climate
Drew inspiration: as thou then hast eyes
To read my wrongs, so be thy head an engine
To raise up ponderous mischief to the height,
And then thy hands the executioners:
A true Italian spirit is a ball
Of wildfire, hurting most when it seems spent;
Great ships on small rocks beating oft, are rent;
And so let Spain by us: but (Malateste)
Why from the presence did you single me
Into this gallery?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To show you, madam,
The picture of yourself, but so defaced,
And mangled by proud Spanyards, it wooed whet
A sword to arm the poorest Florentine
In your just wrongs.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: As how? let's see that picture.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here 'tis then: time is not scarce four days old.
Since I, and certain dons (Sharp-witted fellows,
And of good rank) here with two Jesuits
(Grave profound scholars) in deep argument
Of various propositions; at the last,
Question was moved touching your marriage,
And the ●ings precontract.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: So; and what followed?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Whether it were a question moved by chance●
Or spitefully of purpose (I being there,
And your own countryman) I cannot tell,
But when much tossing
Had bandied both the King and you, as pleased
Those that took up the rackets; in conclusion,
The father Jesuits (To whose subtle music
Every care there was tied) stood with their lives
In stiff defence of this opinion —
o pardon me if I must speak their language.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Say on.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: That the most Catholic King in marrying you,
Keeps you but as his whore.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Are we their themes?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And that Medina's niece (Onaelia)
Is his true wife: her bastard son they said
(The King being dead) should claim and wear the crown;
And whatsoever children you shall bear,
To be but bastards in the highest degree,
As being begotten in adultery.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We will not grieve at this, but with hot vengeance
Beat down this armed mischief: Malateste!
What whirlwinds can we raise to blow this storm
Back in their faces who thus shoot at me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: If I were fit to be your counsellor,
Thus would I speak: feign that you are with child;
The mother of the maids, and some worn ladies,
Who oft have guilty been to court great be ,
May, though it be not so, get you with child
With swearing that 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Say 'tis believed,
Or that it so doth prove?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The joy thereof,
Together with these earthquakes, which will shake
All● pain, if they their prince do disinherit,
So born, of such a Queen; being only daughter
To such a brave spirit as the Duke of Florence,
All this buzzed into the King, he cannot choose
But charge that all the bells in Spain echo up
This joy to heaven; that bonfires change the night
To a high noon, with beams of sparkling flames;
And that in churches, organs (Charmed with prayers)
Speak loud for your most safe delivery.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What fruits grow out of these?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: These; you must stick
(As here and there spring weeds in banks of flowers)
spies amongst the people, who shall lay their ears
To every mouth, and steal to you their whisperings.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis a plummet to sound Spanish hearts
How deeply they are yours: besides, a guess
Is hereby made of any faction
That shall combine against you; which the King seeing,
If then he will not rouse him like a dragon
To guard his golden fleece, and rid his harlot
And her base bastard hence, either by death,
Or in some traps of state, ensnare them both,
Let his own ruins crush him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This goes to trial:
Be thou my magic book, which reading o'er
Their counterspels we'll break; or if the King
Will not by strong hand fix me in his throne,
But that I must be held Spain's blazing star,
Be it an ominous charm to call up war.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Here s●a parcel of man's flesh has been hanging up and down all this morning to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Is't not some executioner?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I see nothing about him to hang in but's garters.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Sent from the King to warn me of my death:
I prithee bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He says he is a poet.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Then bid him better welcome:
Belike he's come to write my epitaph,
Some scurvy thing I warrant; welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Madam, my love presents this book unto you.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: To me? I am not worthy of a line,
Unless at that line hang some hook to choke me:
To the most honoured lady — Onaelia.
Fellow thou liest, I'm most dishonoured:
Thou shouldst have writ to the most wronged lady.
The title of this book is not to me,
I tear it therefore as mine honour's torn.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Your verses are lamed in some of their sect, master poet.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: What does it treat of?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Of the solemn triumphs
Set forth at coronation of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Hissing (The poet's whirlwind) blast thy lines.
Com'st thou to mock my tortures with her triumphs?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Alas madam!

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: When her funerals are past,
Crown thou a dedication to my joys,
And thou shalt swear each line a golden verse:
Cornego, burn this idol.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Your book shall come to light, sir.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I have read legends of disastrous dames;
Will none set pen to paper for poor me?
Canst write a bitter satire? brainless people
Do call 'em libels: dar'st thou write a libel?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I dare mix gall and poison with my ink.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Do it then for me.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: And every line must be
A whip to draw blood.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Better.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: And to dare
The stab from him it touches: he that writes
Such libels (As you call 'em) must launch wide
The fores of men's corruptions, and even search
To'th quick for dead flesh, or for rotten cores:
A poet's ink can better cure some sores
Then surgeons balsam.

sp.speaker: On●e.
sp.l: Undertake that cure,
And crown thy verse with bays.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Madam I le do't:
But I must have the party's character.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I do not love to pluck the quills
With which I make pens, out of a lion's claw:
the King! should I be bitter 'gainst the King,
I shall have scurvy ballads made of me,
Sung to the hanging tune. I dare not, madam.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: This baseness follows your profession:
You are like common beadles, apt to lash
Almost to death poor wretches not worth striking,
But fawn with slavish flattery on damned vices,
So great men act them: you clap hands at those,
Where the true poet indeed doth scorn to guild
A gawdy tomb with glory of his verse,
Which coffins stinking carrion: no, his lines
Are free as his invention; no base fear
Can shake his pen to temporize even with Kings,
The blacker are their crimes, he louder sings.
Go, go, thou canst not write: 'tis but my calling
The muse's help, that I may be inspired:
Cannot a woman be a poet, sir?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Yes, madam, best of all; for poesy
Is but a feigning, feigning is to lie,
And women practise lying more than men.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Nay, but if I should write, I wooed tell truth:
How might I reach a lofty strain?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Thus, madam:
Books, music, wine, brave company, and good cheer,
Make poets to soar high, and sing most clear.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Are they born poets?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Die they?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: O never die.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: My misery is then a poet sure,
For time has given it an eternity:
What sorts of poets are there?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Two sorts, lady:
The great poets, and the small poets.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Great and small!
Which do you call the great? the fat ones?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: No: but such as have great heads, which emptied forth ▪
fill all the world with wonder at their lines;
Fellows which swell big with the wind of praise:
The small ones are but shrimps of poesy.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Which in the kingdom now is the best poet?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Emulation.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Which the next?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Necessity.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: And which the worst?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Self-love.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Say I turn poet, what should I get?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Opinion.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Alas I have got too much of that already;
Opinion is my evidence, judge, and jury;
Mine own guilt, and opinion, now condemn me;
I'll therefore be no poet; no, nor make
Ten muses of your nine; I swear for this;
Verses, though freely born, like slaves are sold,
I crown thy lines with bays, thy love with gold:
So fare thou well.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Our pen shall honour you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: The poet's book, madam, has got the inflammation of the livor, it died of a burning fever.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: What shall I do, Cornego? for this poet
Has filled me with a fury: I could write
Strange satyrs now against adulterers,
And marriage-breakers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I believe you, madam; — but here comes your uncle.

div.stage: Enter Medina, Alanzo, Carlo, Alba, Sebastian, Denia.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Where's our niece?
Turn your brains round, and recollect your spirits,
And see your noble friends and kinsmen ready
To pay revenge his due.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: That word revenge
Startles my sleepy soul, now thoroughly wakened
By the fresh object of my hapless child,
whose wrongs reach beyond mine.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: How doth my sweet mother?

sp.speaker: On●.
sp.l: How doth my prettiest boy?

sp.speaker: Alanz.
sp.l: Wrongs, like great whirlwinds,
Shake highest battlements; few for heaven would care.
Shooed they be ever happy: they are half gods
Who both in good days, and good fortune share.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I have no part in either.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: You shall in both,
Can swords but cut the way.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: I care not much, so you but gently strike him,
And that my child escape the lightning.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: For that our nerves are knit; is there not here
A promising face of manly princely virtues,
And shall so sweet a plant be rooted out
By him that ought to fix it fast i'th ground?
Sebastian, what will you do to him that hurts your mother?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The King my father shall kill him I trow.

sp.speaker: D●n.
sp.l: But, sweet cousin, the King loves not your mother.

sp.speaker: S●b.
sp.l: I'll make him love her when I am a King.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: La you, there's in him a King's heart already:
As therefore we before together vowed,
Lay all your warlike hands upon my sword,
And swear.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Will you swear to kill me, uncle?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: O not for twenty worlds.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay then draw and spare not, for I love fighting.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Stand in the midst (Sweet coz) we are your guard●
These hammers shall for thee beat out a crown
If all hit right; swear therefore (Noble friends)
By your high bloods, by true nobility,
By what you owe religion, owe to your country,
Owe to the raising your posterity,
By love you bear to virtue, and to arms,
(The shield of innocence) swear not to sheathe
Your swords, when once drawn forth.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: O not to kill him
for twenty thousand worlds.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: (Will you be quiet?)
Your swords when once drawn forth, till they ha' forced
You godless, perjurous, perfidious man, —

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Pray rail not at him so.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Art mad? you're idle: — till they ha' forced him
To cancel his late lawless bond he sealed
At the high altar to his Florentine strumpet,
And in his bed lay this his troth-plight wife.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Ay, ay, that's well; pray swear.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: To this we swear.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Uncle, I swear too.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Our forces let's unite, be bold and secret,
And lion-like with open eyes let's sleep,
Streams smooth and slowly running, are most deep.

div.stage: Enter King, Queen, Malateste, Valaseo, Lopez.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The presence door be guarded; let none enter
On forfeit of your lives, without our knowledge:
O you are false physicians all unto me,
You bring me poison, but no antidotes.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Yourself that poison brews.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I will, I must speak more.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thunder aloud.

sp.speaker: Q●ee.
sp.l: My child, yet newly quickened in my womb,
Is blasted with the fires of bastardy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Who! who dares once but think so in his dream?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Medina's faction preached it openly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Be cursed he and his faction: o how I labour
For these preventions! but so cross is fate,
My ills are never hid from me, but their cures:
What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: That which being left undone,
Your life lies at the stake: let 'em be breathless
Both brat and mother.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: She plays true music, sir:
The mischiefs you are drenched in are so full,
You need not fear to add to 'em; since now
No way is left to guard thy rest secure,
But by a means like this.

sp.speaker: Lopez
sp.l: All Spain rings forth
Medina's ruin, and his confederates.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: All his all yes and friends rush into troops
Like raging torrents.

sp.speaker: ●al
sp.l: And loud trumpet forth
Your perjuries: seducing the wild people,
And with rebellious faces threatening all.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I shall be massacred in this their spleen,
Ere I have time to guard myself; I feel
The fire already falling: where's our guard?

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: Planted at garden gate, with a strict charge
That none shall enter but by your command.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let 'em be doubled: I am full of thoughts,
A thousand wheels toss my incertain fears,
There is a storm in my hot boiling brains,
Which rises without wind, a horrid one:
What clamour's that?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Some treason: guard the King.

div.stage: Enter Baltazar drawn; one of the guard falls.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Not in?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: One of your guard's slain, keep off the murderer.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I am none, sir.

sp.speaker: ●al
sp.l: There's a man dropped down by thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou desperate follow, thus press in upon us!
Is murder all the story we shall read?
What ● king can stand, when thus his subjects bleed?
What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: No hurt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Played even the wolf,
And from a fold committed to my charge,
Stolen and devoured one of the flock.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
You've sheep enough for all that, sir; I have killed
none though; or if I have, mine own blood shed in your quarrels, may beg my pardon; my business was in haste to you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I wooed not have thy sin scored on my head
For all the Indian treasury: I prithee tell me,
Suppose thou hadst our pardon, oh can that cure
Thy wounded conscience, can there my pardon help thee
Yet having deserved well both of Spain and us,
We will not pay thy worth with loss of life,
But banish thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: For a groom's death?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No more: we banish thee our court and kingdom:
A King that fosters men so dipped in blood,
May be called merciful, but never good:
Be gone upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Well: farewell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The fellow is not dead but wounded, sir.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: After him, Malateste; in our lodging
Stay that rough fellow, he's the man shall do't:
Haste, or my hopes are lost.
Why are you sad, sir?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: For thee, Paulina, swell my troubled thoughts,
Like billows beaten by too warring winds.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Be you but ruled by me, I'll make a calm
Smooth as the breast of heaven.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Instruct me how.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You (As your fortunes tie you) are inclined
To have the blow given.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where's the instrument?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Tis found in Baltazar.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He's banished.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: True,
But stayed by me for this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His spirit is hot
And rugged, but so honest, that his soul
Will never turn devil to do it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Put it to trial:
retire a little, hither I'll send for him,
Offer repeal and favours if he do it;
But if deny, you have no finger in't,
And then his doom of banishment stands good.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Be happy in thy workings; I obey.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Stay Lopez.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Step to our lodging (Lopez)
And instantly bid Malateste bring
The banished Baltazar to us.

sp.speaker: Lopez
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Thrive my black plots, the mischiefs I have set must not so die; ills must new ills beget.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Now! what hot poisoned custard must I put my spoon into now?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: None, for mine honour now is thy protection.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Which, noble soldier, she will pawn for thee, but never forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair gage, keep it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O Baltazar! I am thy friend, and marked thee;
When the King sentenced thee to banishment
Fire sparkled from thine eyes of rage and grief;
Rage to be doomed so for a groom so base,
And grief to lose thy county: thou hast killed none,
The milksop is but wounded, thou art not banished.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: If I were, I lose nothing, I can make any country mine: I have a private coat for Italian stellettoes, I can be treacherous with the Walloon, drunk with the Dutch, a chimney-sweeper with the Irish, a gentleman with the Welsh, and turn arrant thief with the English, what then is my country to me?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The King (Who raped with fury) banished thee,
Shall give thee favours, yield but to destroy
What him distempers.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: So: and what's the dish I must dress?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Only the cutting off a pair of lives.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I love no red-wine healths.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The King commands it, you are but executioner.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The hangman? An office that will hold so long as hemp lasts, why do not you beg the office, sir?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thy victories in field did never crown thee
As this one act shall.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Prove but that, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Follow him close, he's yielding.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thou shalt be called thy country's patriot,
For quenching out a fire now newly kindling
In factious bosoms, and shalt thereby save
More noble Spanyards lives, than thou slewest Moors.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Art thou not yet converted?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: No point.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Read me then:
Medina's niece (By a contract from the King)
Lays claim to all that's mine, my crown, my bed;
A son she has by him must fill the throne,
If her great faction can but work that wonder:
Now hear me —

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I do with gaping ears.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I swell with hopeful issue to the King.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: A brave don call you mother.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Of this danger
The fear afflicts the King.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Cannot much blame him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If therefore by the riddance of this dame —

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Riddance? o! the meaning on't is murder.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Stab her, or so, that's all.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: That Spain be free from frights, the King ●
And I, now held his infamy, be called Queen,
The treasure of the kingdom shall lie open
To pay thy noble darings.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Come, I le do't, provided I hear Jove call too though he rores; I must have the King's hand to this war● else I dare not serve it upon my conscience

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Be firm then; behold the King is come.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Acquaint him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I found the mettle hard, but with oft beating
He's now so softened, he shall take impression
From any seal you give him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Baltazar, come hither, listen; whatsoever our Queen
Has importuned thee to touching Onaelia,
Niece to the constable, and her young son,
My voice shall second it, and sign her promise.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Their riddance?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: That.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: What way? by poison?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Starving? or strangling, stabbing, smothering?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Any way so 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: But I will have, sir,
This under your own hand, that you desire it,
You plot it, set me on to't.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Pen, ink, and paper.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And then as large a pardon as law and wit
Can engross for me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou shalt ha' my pardon.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: A word more, sir, pray will you tell me one thing?

sp.speaker: King ▪
sp.l: Yes any thing, dear Baltazar.

sp.speaker: ▪ Bal.
sp.l: Suppose
I have your strongest pardon, can that cure
sp.p: My wounded conscience? can there your pardon help me? you not only knock the ewe a'th head, but cut the innocent lamb's throat too, yet you are no butcher.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Is this thy promised yielding to an act
So wholesome for thy country?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Chide him not.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I wooed not have this sin scored on my head
For all the Indaean treasury.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: That song no more:
Do this and I will make thee a great man.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Is there no farther trick in't, but my blow, your purse, and my pardon?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No nets upon my life to entrap thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Then trust me: these knuckles work it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Farewell, be confident and sudden.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Yes:
Subjects may stumble, when Kings walk astray;
Thine acts shall be a new apocrypha.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Medina, Alba, and Daenia, met by Baltazar with a poniard and a pistol.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: You meet a Hydra; see, if one head fails
Another with a sulphurous beak stands yawning

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What hath raised up this devil?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: A great man's vices, that can raise all hell.
What would you call that man, who under-sail,
In a most goodly ship, wherein he ventures
His life, fortunes, and honours, yet in a fury
Should hew the mast down, cast sails overboard,
Fire all the tacklings, and to crown this madness,
Should blow up all the decks, burn th'oaken ribs,
And in that combat 'twixt two elements
Leap desperately, and drown himself i'th seas,
What were so brave a fellow?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A brave black villain.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: That's I; all that brave black villain dwells in me,
If I be that black villain; but I am not,
A nobler character prints out my brow,
Which you may thus read, I was banished Spain
For emptying a court-hogshead, but repealed,
So I wooed (Ere my reeking iron was cold)
Promise to give it a deep crimson dye
in — none hear, — stay — no, none hear.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Whom then?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Basely to stab a woman, your wronged niece,
And her most innocent son Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The boar now foams with whetting.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What has blunted
Thy weapons point at these?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: My honesty;
A sign at which few dwell: (Pure honesty!)
I am a vassal to Medina's house,
He taught me first the a, b, c, of war:
Ere I was truncheon-high, I had the style
Of beardless captain, writing then but boy,
And shall I now turn slave to him that fed me
With cannon-bullets 'And taught me, ostrich-like,
To digest iron and steel! no: yet I yielded
With willow-bendings to commanding breathes.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Of King and Queen: with supple hams,
And an ill-boding look, I vowed to do't:
Yet, lest some choke-pear of state-policy
Shooed stop my throat, and spoil my drinking-pipe,
See (Like his cloak) I hung at the King's elbow,
Till I had got his hand to sign my life.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: Shall we see this and sleep?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: No, whilst these wake.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: 'Tis the King's hand.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Think you me a coiner?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, no, thou art thyself still, noble Baltazar,
● ever knew thee honest, and the mark
Stands still upon thy forehead.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Else flay the skin off.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I ever knew thee valiant, and to scorn
All acts of baseness: I have seen this man
Write in the field such storeys with his sword,
That cur best chieftains swore there was in him
As 'twere a new philosophy of fighting,
his deeds were so punctilious: in one battle,
When death so nearly missed my ribs, he struck
Three horses stone-dead under me: this man,
Three times that day (Even through the jaws of danger)
Redeemed me up, and (I shall print it ever)
Stood o'er my body with colossus thighs,
Whilst all the thunderbolts which war could throw,
Fell on his head: and Baltazar, thou canst not
Be now but honest still, and valiant still,
Not to kill boys and women.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: My byter here, cats no such meat.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Go fetch the marked-out lamb for slaughter hither,
Good fellow-soldier aid him, — and stay — mark,
Give this false fire to the believing King,
That the child's sent to heaven, but that the mother
Stands rocked so strong with friends, ten thousand billows
Cannot once shake her.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: This I'll do.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Away:
Yet one word more; your counsel, noble friends;
Hark Baltazar, because nor eyes nor tongues,
Shall by loud larums, that the poor boy lives,
Question thy false report, the child shall closely
Mantled in darkness, forthwith be conveyed
To the monastery of saint Paul.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Dispatch then, be quick.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: As lightning.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This fellow is some angel dropped from heaven
To preserve innocence.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: He is a wheel
Of swift and turbulent motion; I have trusted him,
Yet will not hang on him too many plummets,
Lest with a headlong cyre he ruins all:
In these state-consternations, when a kingdom
Stands tottering at the center, out of suspicion
Safety grows often; let us suspect this fellow,
and that albeit he show us the King's hand,
It may be but a trick.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: Your lordship hits
A poisoned nail i'th head: this waxen fellow
(By the King's hand so bribing him with gold) is set on screws,
Perhaps is made his creature,
To turn round every way.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Out of that fear
Will I beget truth: for myself in person
Will sound the King's breast.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: How yourself in person?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That's half the prize he gapes for.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I'll venture it,
And come off well I warrant you, and rip up
His very entrails, cut in two his heart,
And search each corner in't, yet shall not he
Know who it is cuts up th' anatomy.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: 'Tis an exploit worth wonder.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Put the worst,
Say some infernal voice should roar from hell,
The infant's cloistering up.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis not our danger,
Nor the imprisoned princes, for what thief
Dares by base sacrilege rob the church of him?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: At worst none can be lost but this slight fellow?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: All build on this as on a stable cube;
If we our footing keep, we fetch him forth,
And crown him King; if up we fly i'th air,
We for his soul's health a broad way prepare.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: They come.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thou knowest where
To bestow him, Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Come moble boy.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Hide him from being discovered.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Discovered? wooed there stood a troop of Moors
Thrusting the paws of hungry lions forth,
to seize this prey, and this but in my hand,
I should do something.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Must I go with this black fellow, uncle?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Yes, pretty coz, hence with him, Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Sweet child, within few minutes I'll change thy fate and take thee hence, but set thee at heaven's gate.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Some keep aloof and watch this soldier.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: D●en.
sp.l: What's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: First to plant strong guard
About the mother, then into some snare
To hunt this spotted panther, and there kill him.

sp.speaker: D●en.
sp.l: What snares have we can hold him?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Be that care mine;
Dangers (Like stars) in dark attempts best shine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: The lady Onaelia dresseth the stead of her commendations in the most courtly attire that words can be clothed with, from herself to you, by me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: So sir; and what disease troubles her now?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: The King's evil; and here she hath sent something to you wrapped up in a white sheet, you need not fear to open it, 'tis no corse.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: What's here? A letter minced into five morsels?
What was she doing when thou camest from her?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: At her pricksong.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Some thinks, for here's nothing but sol-re-me-fa-mi. What Crotchet fills her head now, canst tell?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No crochets, 'tis only the cliff has made her mad.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: What instrument played she upon?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A wind instrument, she did nothing but sigh.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Sol, re, me, fa, mi.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My wit has always had a singing head, I have found out her note captain.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The tune? come.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sol, my foul; re, is all rent and torn like a raggamuffin; me, mend it good captain; fa, fa, what's fa captain?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Fa, why farewell and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Mr., captain, with all my heart; have I tickled my lady's fiddle well?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: O but your stick wants resin to make the strings sound clearly: no, this double virginal, being cunningly touched, another manner of Jack leaps up then is now in mine eye: sol, re, me, fa, mi, I have it now, sol●s rex me facit miseram: alas poor lady, tell her no apothecary in Spain has any of that assafoetida she writes for.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Assafoetida? what's that?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: A thing to be taken in a glister-pipe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why what ails my lady?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: What ails she? why when she cries out, solus rex me facit miseram, she says in the hypocronical language, that she is so miserably tormented with the wind-colic that it racks her very soul.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I said somewhat cut her soul in pieces.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: But go to her, and say the oven is heating.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And what shall be baked in t?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Carpe pies: and besides, tell her the hole in her coat shall be mended: and tell her if the dial of good days go true, why then bounce buckram.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: The devil lies sick of the mulligrubs.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Or the coney is dubbed , and three sheepskins

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With the wrong side outward

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Shall make the fox a nightcap.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So the goose talks French to the buzzard.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: But, sir, if evil days justle our prognostication to the wall, then say there's a fire in a whoremaster's codpiece.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And a poisoned bag-pudding in Tom thumbs belly.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The first cut be thine: farewell.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Wilt not trust an almanac?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nor a coranta neither, though it were sealed with butter, and yet I know where they both lie passing well.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: The King sends round about the court to seek you.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Away otterhound.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Dancing bear, I'm gone.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A private room,
Is't done? hast drawn thy two-edged sword out yet?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: No, I was striking at the two iron bars that hinder your passage, and see sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: What meanst thou?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The edge abated, feel.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: No, no, I see it.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: As blunt as ignorance.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: How? put up — so — how?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: I saw by chance hanging in Cardinal Alvarez gallery a picture of hell.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: So, what of that?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: There lay upon burned straw ten thousand brave fellows all stark naked, some leaning upon crowns, some on mitres, some on bags of gold: glory in another corner lay like a feather beaten in the rain; beauty was turned into a watching candle, that went out stinking: ambition went upon a huge high pair of stilts, but horribly rotten; some in another nook were killing Kings, and some having their elbows shoved forward by Kings to murder others; I was ( methought ) half in hell myself whilst I stood to view this piece.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Was this all?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Was't not enough to see that a man is more healthful that eats dirty puddings, than he that feeds on a corrupted conscience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Conscience! what's that? A conjuring book never opened
Without the reader's danger: 'tis indeed
A scarecrow set i'th world to fright weak fools:
Hast thou seen fields paved o'er with carcases,
Now to be tender-footed, not to tread
On a boy's mangled quarters, and a woman's!

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Nay, sir, I have searched the records of the Low-countries, and find that by your pardon I need not care a pin for goblins, and therefore I will do't sir. I did but recoil because I was double charged.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: No more, here comes a satire with sharp horns.

div.stage: Enter Cardinal, and Medina like a French doctor.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.p: Sir here's a Frenchman charged with some strange which to your close ear only he'll deliver, (Business or else to none.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: A Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: We mounsire.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Cannot he speak the Spanish?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Si signior, ur poco: — monsir acontez in de corner, me come for offer to your bon grace mi trezhumbla service, by gar no John Fidleco shall put into your near braver melody dan dis un petite pipe shall play upon to your great bon grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: What is the tune you'll strike up, touch the string.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Dis; me ha' run up and down mane country, and learn many fine ting, and much knavery, now more and all dis, me know you ha' jumbla de fine vench and fill her belly wid a garcon, her name is le madame —

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Onalia.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: She by gar: now monsire, dis madam send for me to help her malady, being very naught of her corpses (Her body) me know you no point love a dis vensh; but royal monsire donne moye ten tousand French crowns she shall kick up her tail by gar, and beshide lie dead as dog in de shannell.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Speak low.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: As de bagpipe when de wind is puff, gar beigh.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Thou namest ten thousand crowns, I'll treble them rid me but of this leprosy: thy name?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Monsire doctor Devile.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shall ● a second wheel add to this mischief
To set it faster going? If one break,
Th'other may keep his motion.

sp.speaker: M●d.
sp.l: Eslelent fort boon.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Baltazar,
To give thy sword an edge again, this Frenchman
Shall whet them on, that if thy pistol fail,
Or poniard, this can send the poison home.

sp.speaker: B●l.
sp.l: Brother Cain we'll shake hands.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: In de bowl of de bloody busher: 'tis very fine wholesome.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And more to arm your resolution,
I'll tune this churchman so, that he shall chime
In sounds harmonious, merit to that man
Whose hand has but a finger in that act.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: That music were worth hearing.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Holy father,
You must give pardon to me in unlocking
A cave stuffed full with serpents, which my state
Threaten to poison, and it lies in you
To break their bed with thunder of your voice.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How princely son?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Suppose an universal
Hot pestilence beat her mortiferous wings
Oh re all my kingdom, am not I bound in soul
To empty all our academes of doctors,
And Aesculapian spirits to charm this plague?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You are.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Or had the cannon made a breach
Into our rich escurial, down to beat it
about our ears, should I to stop this breach
Spare even our richest ornaments, nay, our crown,
Could it keep bullets off.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: No sir, you should not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This linstock gives you fire: shall then that strumpet
And bastard breathe quick vengeance in my face;
Making my kingdom reel, my subjects stagger
In their obedience, and yet live?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How? live!
Shed not their bloods to gain a kingdom greater
Then ten times this.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Pish, not mattera how redcap and his wit run.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: As I am Catholic King, I'll have their hearts,
Panting in these two hands.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Dare you turn hangman?
Is this religion Catholic to kill
What even bruit beasts abhor to do, (Your own!)
To cut in sunder wedlock's sacred knot
Tied by heavens fingers! to make Spain a bonfire,
To quench which must a second deluge rain
In showers of blood, no water; if you do this,
There is an arm armipotent that can fling you
Into a base grave, and your palaces
With lightning strike, and of their ruins make
A tomb for you (Unpitied, and abhorred)
Bear witness all you lamps celestial
I wash my hands of this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Rise my good angel,
Whose holy tunes beat from me that evil spirit
Which jogs mine elbow, hence thou dog of hell.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Baw wawghe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bark out no more thou mastiff, get you all gone,
And let my soul sleep: there's gold, peace, see it done.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
Sirrah, you Salfa-perilla rascal, toads-guts, you
whoreson pocky French spawn of a bursten-bellied spider, do you hear, monsire.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Why do you bark and snap at my Narcissus, as if I were de french doag?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: You cur of Cerberus' litter
sp.p: You'll poison the honest lady? do but once toot into her chamber-pot, and I'll make thee look worse than a witch does upon a close-stool.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You shall not dare to touch him, stood he here
Single before thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: I'll cut the rat into anchovies.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I'll make thee kiss his hand, embrace him, love him
And call him —

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: The perfection of all Spanyards. Mars in little, the best book of the art of war printed in these times: as a French doctor I wooed have given you pellets for pills, but as my noblest lord, rip my heart out in your service.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thou art the truest clock
That e'er to time paidst tribute, (Honest soldier)
I lost mine own shape, and put on a French,
Only to try thy truth, and the King's falsehood,
Both which I find: now this great Spanish volume
Is opened to me, I read him o'er and o'er,
O what black characters are printed in him.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Nothing but certain ruin threat your niece.
Without prevention: well, this plot was laid
In such disguise to sound him, they that know
How to meet dangers, are the less afraid;
Yet let me counsel you not to text down
These wrongs in red lines.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, I will not, father;
Now that I have anatomised his thoughts,
I'll read a lecture on 'em that shall save
Many men's lives, and to the kingdom minister
Most wholesome surgery; here's our aphorism;
These letters from us in our niece's name,
you know treat of a marriage.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: There's the strong anchor
To stay all in this tempest.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Holy sir,
With these work you the King, and so prevail,
That all these mischiefs hull with flagging sail,

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: My best in this I'll do.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Soldier, thy breast
I must lock better things in.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: 'Tis your chest,
sp.p: With 3 good keys to keep it from opening, an honest heart, a daring hand, and a pocket which scorns money.

div.head: Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Commend us to Medina, say his letters
Right pleasing are, and that (Except himself)
Nothing could be more welcome: counsel him
(To blot the opinion out of factious numbers)
Only to have his ordinary train
Waiting upon him: for, to quit all fears
Upon his side of us, our very court
Shall even but, dimly shine with some few dons,
Freely to prove our longings great to peace.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: The constable expects some pawn from you.
That in this fairy circle shall rise up
No fury to confound his niece nor him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: A King's word is engaged.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: It shall be taken.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Valasco, call the captain of our guard,
Bid him attend us instantly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Lopez come hither: see
Letters from Duke Medina, both in the name
Of him and all his faction, offering peace,
And our old love (His niece) Onaelia
In marriage with her free and fair consent
To Cockadillia, a don of Spain.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Will you refuse this?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My crown as soon: they feel their sinewy plots
Belike to shrink i'th joints; and fearing ruin,
Have found this cement out to piece up all,
Which more endangers all.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How sir endangers!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Lion's may hunted be into the snare,
But if they once break loose, woe be to him
That first seized on 'em. A poor prisoner scorns
To kiss his jailor; and shall a King be choked
With sweetmeats, by false traitors! no, I will fawn
On them, as they stroke me, till they are fast
But in this paw: and then.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A brave revenge.
The captain of your guard.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Upon thy life
Double our guard this day: let every man
Bear a charged pistol, hid; and at a watchword
Given by a musket, when ourself sees time,
Rush in; and if Medina's faction wrestle
Against your forces, kill; but if yield, save:
Be secret.

sp.speaker: Alanz.
sp.l: I am charmed, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Watch, Valasco,
If any wear a cross, feather, or glove,
Or such prodigious signs of a knit faction,
Table their names up: at our ourt-gate plant
Good strength to bar them out, if once they swarm:
Do this upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not death shall fright me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: 'Tis done, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Death! what's done?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Young cub's flayed,
But the she-fox shifting her hole is fled;
The little jackanapes the boy's brained.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sebastian?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: He shall never speak more Spanish.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou teachest me to curse thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: For a bargain you set your hand to.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Half my crown I'd lose, were it undone.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: But half a crown! that's nothing:
His brains stick in my conscience more than yours.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How lost I the French doctor?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: As Frenchmen lose their hair: here was too hot staying for him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Get thou too from my sight, the Queen would see thee.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Your gold, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go with Judas and repent.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: So men hate whores after lust's heat is spent:
I'm gone, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tell me true, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No matter; 'tis but morning of revenge,
The sunset shall be red and tragical.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Sin is a raven creaking her own fall.

div.stage: Enter Medina, Daenia, Alba, Carlo, and the faction with rosemary in their hats.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Keep locked the door, and let none enter to us
But who shares in our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: Lock the doors.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What entertainment did the King bestow
Upon your letters and the Cardinals?

sp.speaker: M●d.
sp.l: With a devouring eye he read 'em o'er,
Swallowing our offers into his empty bosom,
as gladly as the parched earth drinks healths
Out of the cup of heaven.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Little suspecting
What dangers closely lie enambushed.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: Let not us trust to that; there's in his bre●t
Both fox and lion, and both those beasts can bite:
We must not now behold the narrowest loop-hole,
But presently suspect a winged bullet
Flies whizzing by our ears.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: For when I let
The plummet fall to sound his very soul
In his close-chamber, being french-doctor like,
He to the Cardinal's ear sung sorcerous notes,
The burden of his song, to mine, was death,
Onaelia's murder, and Sebastian's;
