And think you his voice alters now? 'tis strange,
To see how brave this tyrant shows in court,
Throned like a god: great men are petty stars,
Where his rays shine, wonder fills up all eyes
By sight of him, let him but once check sin,
About him round all cry, o excellent King!
O saintlike man! but let this King retire
Into his closet to put off his robes,
He like a player leaves his part off too;
Open his breast, and with a sunbeam search it,
There's no such man; this King of gilded clay,
Within is ugliness, lust, treachery,
And a base soul, though reared collossus-high.

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: None till he speaks, and that we know his voice:
Who are you?

sp.speaker: Within Bal.
sp.l: An honest housekeeper in Rosemary-lane too,
If you dwell in the same parish.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: O 'tis our honest soldier, give him entrance.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p:
Men show like corses, for I meet few but are stuck with rosemary: every one asked me who was married today
, and I told 'em adultery and repentance, and that shame and a hangman followed 'em to church.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: There's but two parts to play, shame has done hers,
But execution must close up the scane,
And for that cause these sprigs are worn by all,
Badges of marriage, now of funeral,
For death this day turns courtier

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Who must dance with him?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The King, and all that are our opposites:
That dart or this must fly into the court
Either to shoot this blazing star from Spain,
Or else so long to wrap him up in clouds,
Till all the fatal fires in him burn out,
Leaving his state and conscience clear from doubt
Of following uproars.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Kill not, but surprise him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: That's my voice still.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thine, soldier.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: O this colic of a kingdom, when the wind of treason gets amongst the small guts, what a rumbling and a roaring it keeps: and yet make the best of it you can, it goes out stinking: kill a King?

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: If men should pull the sun out of heaven every time 'tis eclipsed, not all the wax nor tallow in Spain would serve to make us candles for one year.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: No way to purge the sick state, but by opening a vain.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Is that your French physic? if every one of us should be whipped according to our faults, to be lashed at a cart's tail would be held but a flea-biting.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What are you? come you from the King?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: No? more no's? I know him, let him enter.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Signior, I thank your kind intelligence,
The news long since was sent into our ears.
Yet we embrace your love, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Will you smell to a sprig of rosemary?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Will you be hanged?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: This is either signior no, or no signior.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: He makes his love to us a warning-piece
To arm ourselves against we come to court,
Because the guard is doubled.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Tush, we care not.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: If any here arms his hand to cut off the head, let him first pluck out my throat: in any noble act I le wade chin-deep with you: but to kill a King?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: No, hear me —

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: You were better, my lord, sail 500 times to Bantom in the West-indies, than once to Barathrum in the Low-countries: it's hot going under the line there, the calenture of the soul is a most miserable madness.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Turn then this wheel of fate from shedding blood
Till with her own hand justice weighs all.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Must then his trul be once more sphered in court
To triumph in my spoils, in my eclipses?
And I like moping Juno sit, whilst Jove
Varies his lust into five hundred shapes
To steal to his whore's bed! no, Malateste,
Italian fires of jealousy burn my marrow;
For to delude my hopes, the lecherous King
Cuts out this robe of cunning marriage,
To cover his incontinence, which flames
Hot (As my fury) in his black desires:
I am swollen big with child of vengeance now,
And till delivered, feel the throws of hell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Just is your indignation, high, and noble,
And the brave heat of a true Florentine;
For Spain trumpets abroad her interest
in the King's heart, and with a black coal draws
On every wall your scoffed at injuries,
As one that has the refuse of her sheets,
And the sick autumn of the weakened King,
Where she drunk pleasures up in the full spring.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: That (Malateste) that, that torrent wracks me●
But Hymen's torch (Held downward) shall drop out,
And for it, the mad furies swing their brands
About the bride-chamber.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The priest that joins them,
Our twin-born malediction.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Lowd may it speak.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The herbs and flowers to strew the wedding way,
Be cypress, yew, cold colliquintida.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Henbane and Poppey, and that magical weed
Which hags at midnight watch to catch the seed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To these our execrations, and what mischief
Hell can but hatch in a distracted brain,
I le be the executioner, though it look
So horrid it can fright e'en murder back.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Poison his whore today, for thou shalt wait
On the King's cup, and when heated with wine
He calls to drink the bride's health, marry her
Alive to a gaping grave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: At board?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: At board.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: When she being guarded round about with friends,
Like a fair island, hemmed with rocks and seas,
What rescue shall I find?

sp.speaker: Q●●e.
sp.l: Mine arms: dost faint?
Stood all the Pyrenaean hills that part
Spain and our country, on each others shoulders,
Burning with Aetnean flame, yet thou shouldst on,
As being my steel of resolution,
First striking sparkles from my flinty breast:
Wert thou to catch the horses of the sun
Fast by their bridles, and to turn back day,
wouldst thou not do't (Base coward) to make way
To the Italians second revenge (Revenge.)

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Were my bones threatened to the wheel of torture
I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: A raven's voice, and it likes me well.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The King expects your presence.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: So, so, we come
To turn this bride's day to a day of doom.

div.stage: A banquet set out, cornets sounding; enter at one door Lopez, Valasco, Alanzo, no: after them King, Cardinal, with don cockadillio bridegroom, Queen and Malateste after. At the other door Alba, Carlo, Roderigo, Medina and Daenia leading Onaelia as bride, Cornego and Juanna after, Bartazar alone, bride and bridegroom kiss, and by the Cardinal are joined hand in hand: King is very merry, hugging Medina very lovingly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: For half Spain's weight in ingots I'd not lose
This little man today.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Nor for so much
Twice told, sir, would I miss your kingly presence;
Mine eyes have lost th'acquaintance of your face
So long, and I so (Little) late read o'er
That index of the royal book your mind,
That scarce (Without your comment) can I tell
When in those leaves you turn o'er smiles or frowns.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Tis dimness of your sight, no fault i'th letter:
Medina, you shall find that free from erratas:
And for a proof,
If I could breathe my heart in welcomes forth,
This hall should ring naught else; welcome Medina,
Good marquess Daenia, dons of Spain all welcome:
My dearest love and Queen, be it your place
To entertain the bride, and do her grace.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: With all the love I can, whose fire is such,
to give her heat, I cannot burn too much.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Contracted bride, and bridegroom sit,
Sweet flowers not plucked in season, lose their scent,
So will our pleasures; father Cardinal,
Methinks this morning new-begins our reign.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Peace had her sabbath never till now in Spain.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where is our noble soldier Baltazar?
So close in conference with that signior?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What think'st thou of this great day, Baltazar?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: Of this day? why as of a new play, if it ends well, all's well; all men are but actors, now if you being the King, should be out of your part, or the Queen out of hers, or your dons out of theirs, here's no will never be out of his ▪

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: 'Twere a lamentable piece of stuff to see great statesmen have vile exits; but I hope there are nothing but plaudities in all your eyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Mine I protest are free.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And mine by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Free from one good look till the blow be given.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Wine; a full cup crowned to Medina's health.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Your highness this day so much honours me,
That I to pay you what I truly owe,
My life shall venture for it.

sp.speaker: D●●n.
sp.l: So shall mine.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Onaelia, you are sad: why frowns your brow?

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: A foolish memory of my past ills
Folds up my look in furrows of old care,
But my heart's merry, sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which mirth to heighten,
Your bridegroom and yourself first pledge this health
Which we begin to our high constable.

div.stage: Three cups filled: 1. to the King. 2. to the bridegroom. 3. to Onaelia, with whom the King compliments.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Is 't speeding?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As all our Spanish figs are.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Here's to Medina's heart with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My heart shall pledge your heart i'th deepest draught
That ever Spaniard drank.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Medina mocks me,
Because I wrong her with the largest bowl:
I'll change with thee, Onaelia.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Sir you shall not.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Fear you I cannot fetch it off!

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Malateste!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This is your scorn to her, because I am doing
This poorest honour to her: music sound,
It goes were it ten fathoms to the ground.

div.stage: Cornets. King drinks, Queen and Mal. storms.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fate strikes with the wrong weapon.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Sweet royal sir no more, it is too deep.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twill hurt your health sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Interrupt me in my drink: 'tis off.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Alas sir;
You have drunk your last, that poisoned bowl I filled
Not to be put into your hand, but hers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Poisoned?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Descend black speckled soul to hell.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The Queen has sent me thither.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: What new fury shakes now her snakes locks.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Ay, ay, 'tis I;
Whose soul is torn in pieces, till I send
This harlot home.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: More murders! save the lady.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Rampant? let the constable make a mittimus.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Keep 'em asunder.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: How is it, royal son?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I feel no poison yet, only mine eyes
Are putting out their lights: methinks I feel
Death's icy fingers stroking down my face; and now
I'm in a mortal cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Q●ee.
sp.l: Dear my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hence, call in my physicians.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thy physician, tyrant,
Dwells yonder, call on him or none.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bloody Medina, stab'st thou Brutus too?

sp.speaker: Daen.
sp.l: As he is, so are we all.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I burn,
My brains boil in a cauldron, oh one drop
Of water now to cool me.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: O let him have physicians.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Keep her backe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Physicians for my soul, I need none else;
You'll not deny me those: o holy father,
Is there no mercy hovering in a cloud
For me a miserable King so drenched
In perjury and murder?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: O sir great store.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Come down, come quickly down.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I'll forthwith send
For a grave friar to be your confessor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: And he shall cure your wounded soul:
Fetch him good soldier.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: So good a work I'll hasten.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Onaelia! o she's drowned in tears! Onaelia,
Let me not die unpardoned at thy hands.

div.stage: Enter Baltazar, Sebastian as a friar, with others.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Here comes a better surgeon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hail my good son,
I come to be thy ghostly father.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha? my child 'tis my Sebastian, or some spirit
Sent in his shape to fright me.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.p: 'Tis no gobbling, i●, feel; your own flesh and blood, and much younger than you though he be bald, and calls you son; had I been as ready to ha' cut his sheep's throat, as you were to send him to the shambles, he had bleated no more; there's less chalk upon you score of sins by these round o'es.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O my dull soul look up, thou art somewhat lighter,
Noble Medina, see Sebastian lives:
Onaelia cease to weep, Sebastian livea;
Fetch me my crown: my sweetest pretty friar,
Can my hands do't, I le raise thee one step higher
Thou'st been in heaven's house all this while sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I had but course cheer.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou couldst never fare better:
Religious houses are those hives, where bees
Make honey for men's souls: I tell thee, boy,
A friary is a cube, which strongly stands,
Fashioned by men, supported by heavens hands:
Order of holy priesthood are as high
I'th eyes of angels, as a King's dignity:
Both these unto a crown give the hill weight,
And both are thine: you that our contract know,
See how I seal it with this marriage;
My blessing and Spain's kingdom both be thine.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: Doff that friars course grey;
And since he's crowned a King, clothe him like one.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O no: those are right sovereign ornaments;
Had I been clothed so, I had never filled
My work is almost finished: where's my Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Here piecemeal torn by furies.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Onaelia!
Your hand Paulina too, Onaelia yours:
This hand (The pledge of my twice broken faith)
By you usurped is her inheritance;
My love is turned, see as my fate is turned,
Thus they today laugh, yesterday which mourned:
I pardon thee my death; let her be sent
Back into Florence with a trebled dowry;
Death comes: o now I see what late I feared!
A contract broke, though pieced up ne'er so well,
Heaven sees, earth suffers, but it ends in hell.

sp.speaker: Onae.
sp.l: O I could die with him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Since the bright sphere
I moved in falls, alas what make I here?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The hammers of black mischief now cease beating,
Yet some irons still are heating: you, sir bridegroom,
(Set all this while up as a mark to shoot at)
We here discharge you of your bedfellow,
She loves no barbers washing.

sp.speaker: Co●ck.
sp.l: My balls are saved then.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Be it your charge, so please you reverend sir,
To see the late Queen safely sent to Florence:
My niece Onaelia, and that trusty soldier,
We do appoint to guard the infant King:
Other distractions, time must reconcile;
The state is poisoned like a crocodile.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
